large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Literacy:Print Concepts; Read-Aloud Comprehension; Alphabet Knowledge

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about the alphabet (Ff, Ll, Mm), engage children with song and rhymes, and introduce the vocabulary (whine, between).
Begin Story Time by introducing the guiding question: What happens when a dinosaur gets the flu?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand conventions of print including end punctuation and case.
Uses information to describe.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Talk and share.
Exercise good habits of personal health and hygiene.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review the sounds for Ff, Ll, and Mm with children.
Give children alphabet books to explore: What Can You Find?, The Little Lion, and My Mess.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find a character in your book who doesn’t feel well?
Pretend you are a sick dinosaur. How would you act?
Can you name two things you may do to get well if you’re sick?
Can you write what you would tell a sick dino to do to get well soon?
Can you draw your favorite dino from the book?
Can you say the sounds made by the letters Ff, Ll, and Mm?
How can you build a place for a dino to rest until he feels better?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders:Emotional Development; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder move carefully through surroundings and Talk and Share and introduce the vocabulary (share).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to the book How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon ?
Read closely and discuss the Mind Builders.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Identify at least 20 uppercase and at least 20 lowercase letters in text.
Understand conventions of print, including end punctuation and case.
Identify their own bodies within surroundings and respects others’ personal space.
Talk and share.
Exercise good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Emotional Development; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to create Stegosaurus dinosaur puppets.
Have children use their puppets to practice respecting personal space.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find ways that the characters in your book respect each others’ personal space?
What sounds does a sick dino make? Can you make those sounds?
Can you make a number game with counters for sick dinosaurs to play?
Imagine you had a real personal-space bubble that eveyrone could see. Can you write about what that would be like?
Can you draw your personal-space bubble? Show yourself inside it!
Can you draw things that start with the letter Ff?
Can you build a personal-space bubble around yourself?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Literacy:Read-Aloud Comprehension; Print Concepts; Phonological Awareness

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background on healthy habits and introduce the vocabulary (whispers).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and ask: What can a dinosaur do to get well soon?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check for understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Identify rhyming words.
Make inferences.
Understand conventions of print, including end punctuation and case.
Write for different purposes.
Talk and share.
Exercise good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Use art for self-expression.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children identify rhyming words in pictures and print.
Guide children to create get well cards for a sick dinosaur.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are the characters in your book like the dinosaurs in our story?
What would you tell a sick dinosaur to do to get well soon?
Can you pretend you’re a sick dinosaur and quietly work on some puzzles?
Can you write about a time when you were sick?
Can you make a dinosaur stick puppet?
Can you draw things that start with the letter Ll?
Can you build a doctor’s office for the sick dinosaur?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon? by Jane Yolen, illustrated by Mark Teague. Text copyright © 2003 by Jane Yolen. Illustrations copyright © 2003 by Mark Teague. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © Aleksey Sagitov/Shutterstock.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Keep Your Hands Clean

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce the Big Chart of Big Ideas; talk about healthy habits, and introduce the vocabulary (scrub, rinse).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Keep Your Hands Clean and How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe; relate own experiences to those in books.
Write for different purposes.
Talk and share.
Exercise good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children practice the healthy habit of handwashing after their hands get dirty.
Guide children to follow and order the directions for handwashing.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Why do we wash our hands?
Pretend your hands are covered with sticky goo. How will you get them clean?
Put these steps for washing hands in the correct order: Dry, Rinse, Scrub, Soap, Wet
Can you write about why we should wash our hands?
Trace your hand on a piece of paper. Can you decorate it?
Can you put these letters in alphabetical order: l, f, m?
Can you build a step to help a dinosaur or animal reach the sink?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon? by Jane Yolen, illustrated by Mark Teague. Text copyright © 2003 by Jane Yolen. Illustrations copyright © 2003 by Mark Teague. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © originalpunkt/Shutterstock.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to sing a song and review vocabulary (share, between).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking the guiding question: What might children do if they get the flu?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and enjoyment.
Check for understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing activity.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share and repeat details in a text.
Write for different purposes.
Talk and share.
Exercise good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s writing prompt: When you’re sick, what might you do to get well?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Which sick dinosaur that we’ve read about is your favorite?
Can you pretend to be a doctor? How would you take care of the sick dinosaurs?
Can you find the real names of the dinosaurs hidden in the book?
Imagine you are taking care of a sick dinosaur. Can you write about it?
Draw a picture of your favorite dino from the book.
Can you draw things that start with the letter Mm?
Can you build a bed where the sick dinosaur can rest?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon? by Jane Yolen, illustrated by Mark Teague. Text copyright © 2003 by Jane Yolen. Illustrations copyright © 2003 by Mark Teague. Published by Scholastic Inc.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Identify some conventional features of print that communicate meaning including end punctuation and case.
Use information learned from books by describing relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Talk and share.
Practice good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Identify some conventional features of print that communicate meaning including end punctuation and case.
Are aware of their own bodies in space and respect personal boundaries.
Talk and share.
Practice good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Use a variety of art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
Recognize rhyming words.
Make inferences and predictions about text.
Identify some conventional features of print that communicate meaning including end punctuation and case.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Talk and share.
Practice good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
Uses information learned from books by describing relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Talk and share.
Practice good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Talk and share.
Practice good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
